newsitem.title: USA: Metris president backs 1997 EPS estimate.
newsitem.headline: Metris president backs 1997 EPS estimate.

text.p: Metris Cos Inc President Ronald Zebeck said Monday he is comfortable with the current mean earnings estimate for 1997 of $1.65 a share.
"I believe we're right on track...We feel very comfortable with those numbers," Zebeck said after the shareholders' meeting here Monday.
The First Call mean estimate for 1997 of $1.65 a share is a 42 percent increase over the $1.16 a share earned in 1996.
"The fact that we're servicing a segment the traditional (credit card) issuers are not competing in gives us a good feeling that we can go and grow at 42 percent levels very well," Zebeck said.
Metris, a consumer credit company, targets households with annual earnings of $15,000 to $35,000, which it says represents almost one third of total U.S. households.

Zebeck said he expects Metris would have a 36 to 50 percent increase in the number of credit card accounts in 1997 compared with 1.4 million accounts at the end of 1996. He also expects a 63 percent increase in account balances in 1997 compared with $1.6 billion at the end of 1996.

"They (analysts) are looking for us to grow about 500,000 to 700,000 new accounts (in 1997), and I'm comfortable with those numbers," Zebeck said. "If we can grow by a billion dollars in outstandings (accounts receivable), I'd be very pleased."
Zebeck said he expected Metris' net charge-off ratio, or net charge offs expressed as a percentage of average loans outstanding, to increase to 10.5 percent in 1997 from 6.7 percent in 1996.
